ORAL ANSWER TO QUESTION
STANDARDISED MALAY PRONUNCIATION IN SCHOOLS
(Introduction)


    1. Mr Umar Abdul Hamid asked the Minister for Education if there is any plan to implement "Bahasa Baku" in the school curriculum.

     The Minister of State for Education (Encik Sidek bin Saniff) (for the Minister for Education): Sir, I am answering on behalf of my Minister.

    The Ministry of Education will introduce the standardised Malay pronunciation (Sebutan Baku) in primary schools with effect from 1993 and in secondary schools and junior colleges with effect from 1994. This move is to enable us to keep pace with the developments in the Malay Language in the region. Oral examinations based on the standardised pronunciation will be gradually phased in. The first examinations based on this pronunciation system will be held in 1997 for 'N', '0' and 'A' level candidates and in 1998 for PSLE candidates. Training sessions will be conducted for teachers later this year to equip them with the knowledge to teach the standardised Malay pronunciation.

     Mr Umar Abdul Hamid (Ang Mo Kio GRC): Sir, may I be allowed to ask supplementary questions in Malay, please?

     Mr Speaker: Yes.

     Mr Umar Abdul Hamid( In Malay): Mr Speaker, I have three supplementary questions. Firstly, could the Minister of State give a background of the development of standardised Malay pronunciation in the neighbouring countries of Malaysia, Indonesia and Brunei? Secondly, what role can the mass media or the electronic media play in promoting the standardised Malay pronunciation? And thirdly, once we have achieved our objective of introducing "Sebutan Baku", can we not play a more active role by being a member of the Malaysia-Indonesia-Brunei Malay Language Committee (MABBIM)?

Column: 1339



     Encik Sidek bin Saniff( In Malay): Mr Speaker, there are four countries involved in the move to standardise Malay pronunciation. Indonesia started it way back in 1928, following the Youth Pledge: one people, one nation, one language. For Brunei, there is no problem because their pronunciation is already standardised on the basis of spelling. The difference, if at all, is that they pronounce the schwa sound as if the word is spelt with an 'a'. But they follow the correct pronunciation once they switch to standard Malay.

    The problem really lies in two countries - Malaysia and Singapore. Malaysia has been taking a cautious approach. They started it in 1988 and expect the process to take about 15 years. We, too, have gone into it very cautiously. As I have stated earlier, we would begin next year with the primary schools and the following year with the secondary schools. And the oral examinations would be conducted only when our primary school children have gone through six years of education, and those in secondary school have gone through four, using this pronunciation.

    I think this cautious approach is necessary because we do not want to unsettle the public. For myself and my colleagues in the Ministry, our targets are the school children, and only after them will we go on to the public. Of course, if the public can use the standardised pronunciation in formal settings, I think that would be ideal. Mr Mah Bow Tan, for example, became the first, when he closed the Malay Language Month, to use not just Malay but standardised Malay pronunciation, in such a formal ceremony.

    Secondly, on the mass media, I think we have to be even more cautious here. Right now, in Malaysia, for example, this cautiousness has been evident. They do not use standardised pronunciation over radio, particularly in news reading, especially on television. They use standardised pronunciation only on TV3 - commercial TV. Even in Malaysia, if I could quote a language writer, Zakariah Mohd Yassin, he believes it would take the electronic media at least 10

Column: 1340

years. So I think we are looking at 1998, as far as the Malaysian electronic media or TV is concerned.

    On our part, I think we can do it step by step, carefully, while meeting our expectations. We could perhaps start with a programme over radio or television that uses standardised pronunciation. But where it concerns something that is open to the larger population, eg, the news, I think two things need to be done. Firstly, we look to Malaysia for the signal; and secondly, we go about it in an even more meticulous manner.

    On the third question, I think this point has been raised many times, even recently when I attended the MABBIM meeting. The stalwarts, Malaysia and Indonesia, have been encouraging Singapore to raise its participation status, from mere observer to full membership. I would raise this issue with my colleague, the Minister for Information and the Arts, BG Yeo, so that we could look into this together.

     Encik Ibrahim bin Othman (Thomson GRC) (In Malay - Sebutan Baku): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State what measures will be taken by the Ministry to train teachers in order that they could teach this pronunciation more effectively. Secondly, what is the Minister of State's view on the usage of standardised pronunciation over radio and television? And thirdly, what programmes does the Minister have in mind to encourage the public to use the standardised pronunciation correctly?

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff (In Malay - Sebutan Baku) : Mr Speaker, since Encik Ibrahim Othman has used the standardised pronunciation, I guess I will have to do the same.

    Concerning the measures, as I said earlier, a seminar would be conducted later this year for primary and secondary school teachers. The four-day seminar will be organised with the cooperation of foreign experts, possibly two from Malaysia and one from Indonesia. Secondly, for radio, as I said earlier, we are going to go about it cautiously. We hope to discuss with SBC the idea of launching some programmes

Column: 1341

relating to the standardised pronunciation. As for further measures, we are looking into them in detail now. I have identified certain areas and have been working them out together with our officials over the past several months. In fact, we had our latest discussion yesterday. And I hope to be able to announce the plans once they are finalised.

     Encik Harun bin A. Ghani (Hong Kah GRC)( In Malay): Sir, I would like to ask the Minister of State why we have to walk in the shadows of Malaysia in this regard. Why must we wait for Malaysia to take the initiative when we can do it as soon as possible?

     Encik Sidek bin Saniff( In Malay): Thank you for the question. I think the national component in Malaysia is ethnically the same as us, but the socio-political position is different. For the moment, that is our stand, as stated earlier. They contain a larger population. We are only about 3 million. Secondly, this cautious approach is perhaps inspired by our Foreign Affairs Ministry - when we were going to recognise China, for example, we waited until Indonesia had taken the first step. So I think, in this regard, it is better to give way. We wait until Malaysia has finalised everything on its part. Then our wheels of implementation can move more smoothly.

TRADE DEVELOPMENT BOARD (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Before I describe the contents of the Bill, may I brief Members on the background to the Bill as well as to the next two which will also deal with the regulation of the rubber trade.

    Singapore is the world's leading centre for physical and futures rubber trading. In the 1960s, because of the importance of

Column: 1342

this trade, the Government set up the Rubber Association of Singapore (RAS) as a statutory body under the Rubber Association of Singapore (Incorporation) Act.

    The RAS licenses rubber packers, shippers and manufacturers of technically specified rubber under the Rubber Industry Act. It also issues licences for the purchase, treatment and storage of rubber under the Rubber Dealers Act. In addition, the Association provides a market place for rubber futures trading and regulates it under the Rubber Association of Singapore (Incorporation) Act.

    Although the RAS is a statutory board, it has in the past operated almost independently of Government supervision. This was because there were inadequate provisions in the legislation to enable the Government to make changes to the modus operandi of the rubber trade. The rubber trade has had considerable latitude to self-regulate and has relied on trust and established relationships to do business. This has from time to time caused problems. In 1986, there was a near default by a local trader in the rubber market, and in 1989 the insolvency of a broker threatened the stability of the system. These episodes clearly highlighted the need to restructure and modernise the rubber futures trading system in line with other international commodity exchanges.

    To prevent a recurrence of similar problems and to make the Singapore rubber market more attractive, MTI appointed a review committee, called the RAS Review Steering Committee, to draw up a long term strategy to develop the market. This Committee comprised representatives from RAS, MAS, TDB, MTI and SIMEX. They consulted the trade, identified weaknesses in the rubber market and proposed ways to develop Singapore into an international trading centre. Specifically, the Committee recommended that, firstly, the RAS be privatised to provide a central market place for rubber futures trading; secondly, the regulatory and promotional functions of the RAS in physical rubber trade be transferred to the Trade Development Board (TDB);

Column: 1343

and thirdly, that TDB supervises the private exchange.

    These three Bills put these recommendations into effect. They will empower TDB to supervise the overall regulatory framework of the rubber trade. TDB has also helped the new exchange to draft its house rules, to tighten up on prudential requirements and safeguard the integrity of the market.

    With this background, I will highlight the main provisions of the Bill.

    This Bill expands section 5 of the TDB Act to enable the Board to promote, facilitate and regulate futures trading in rubber and other commodities as may be approved by Government in future.

    The Bill also proposes to insert a new Part VIA to provide for the transfer of functions, assets, rights, liabilities and the Singapore Rubber Fund from the RAS to the TDB. Rubber Association staff will be transferred to the TDB on no less favourable terms than those they enjoy immediately before their transfer.

    The Bill transfers the Singapore Rubber Fund from the RAS to the TDB. It provides for the Fund to be used for the following purposes:

    Firstly, the promotion, development, regulation and maintenance of the commodity trade and industry, including the commodity futures market in Singapore;

    Secondly, the payment of all expenses necessary for the participation in international natural rubber organisations and agreements established under these organisations.

    Thirdly, the discharge of any outstanding liability incurred by the RAS and transferred to the TDB.

    And fourthly, for putting into effect the Rubber Industry Act 1992 and the discharge of any liability arising as a result of the exercise of the function and duties under that Act.

    The privatisation of the RAS makes it necessary to repeal the Rubber Association

Column: 1344

of Singapore (Incorporation) Act. This is also provided under the Bill.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [BG Lee Hsien Loong].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

RUBBER INDUSTRY BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The Rubber Industry Bill 1992 is a merger of two Acts, namely, the Rubber Industry Act 1973 and the Rubber Dealers Act 1921, both of which are administered by the RAS. It seeks to repeal the two old Acts and to re-enact with amendments the Rubber Industry Act for the promotion, regulation and control of the natural rubber trade and industry.

    This Bill consolidates all regulations related to the physical trade in rubber, including the manufacture of technically specified rubber, the packing and shipping of rubber for export, and dealing in rubber. It makes no substantive changes to what is currently provided for in the existing Rubber Industry and Rubber Dealers Acts, except for transferring the regulatory functions presently vested in the Rubber Association of Singapore to the TDB.

    I will now elaborate on the main provisions of the Bill. Clause 2 defines "deal" to cover buying, selling and brokering of physical rubber except futures trading which will be regulated under the Commodity Futures Bill, 1992. Persons who trade in rubber for physical delivery at a future date are also regulated by this Bill.

    Clause 3, subclauses (4) and (5) are retained to maintain the historical reciprocal arrangements with Malaysia whereby a licence to ship rubber for export issued by the competent authority in Malaysia is

Column: 1345

deemed to be a valid licence for use in Singapore and vice versa.

    Clause 12 provides for licensees whose licences have been suspended or revoked, or who have been disciplined by the TDB, to appeal to an Appeal Tribunal. The Tribunal's terms of office, qualification for appointment and powers, are spelt out in Clause 13.

    Clause 14 spells out the functions of the TDB in promoting and developing the rubber trade. The functions were adopted from the Rubber Association of Singapore (Incorporation) Act.

    To expedite administration and regulation of licensees, TDB is empowered under clause 27 to make by-laws to regulate the conduct of the rubber trade and industry. Clause 28 empowers the TDB to exempt any person from the provisions of the Bill subject to the Minister's approval.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [BG Lee Hsien Loong].

COMMODITY FUTURES BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for Trade and Industry (BG Lee Hsien Loong): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    Hitherto, the rubber futures market in Singapore has been managed by the RAS under the RAS (Incorporation) Act. For the reasons I have explained, this arrangement has not been satisfactory. The Government is now passing this Bill to subject the rubber futures market to formal regulation.

    There is already on the statute books the Futures Trading Act (FTA), administered by the Monetary Authority of Singapore, which regulates futures trading in currencies, interest rates, stock indices, oil and gold. MTI considered bringing rubber futures

Column: 1346

trading under the Futures Trading Act, but found the FTA inappropriate for this purpose. It has instead decided on separate legislation to regulate the rubber futures market for the following reasons.

    Firstly, futures trading in the Singapore International Monetary Exchange (SIMEX) uses the open outcry system, whereas rubber futures trading uses the market making system, also known as the whispering system, in which transactions are executed over the telephone. The rubber trade has requested that this should continue in future, because of the small circle of international traders, producers and consumers of rubber, and the more stable rubber prices. The Review Committee has accepted this recommendation.

    Secondly, SIMEX currently operates a mutual offset arrangement with the Chicago Mercantile Exchange. Incorporating rubber futures trading with its different trading system would complicate this arrangement. For prudent administration, it is also preferable for the FTA to continue to deal exclusively with financial futures trading.

    The Commodity Futures Bill contains the new legislation to regulate futures trading in rubber and in other commodities. The privatised RAS, now incorporated as the RAS Commodity Exchange Ltd, will operate the market for trading rubber futures as the first contract on the Exchange.

    At present, the scope of the Bill is limited to regulating trading in rubber futures contracts. Other commodity futures contracts will be prescribed as and when they become commercially viable. Until this is done, futures trading based on other commodities, for example, coffee or red beans, will not be regulated by the law. Persons who trade with broking firms offering such facilities have to bear the risks involved themselves.

    This Bill is modelled very closely to the FTA, and incorporates a number of key features of the FTA. The differences arise largely from the way the trade is carried out, that is, the market making or whispering system in the RAS Commodity

Column: 1347

Exchange versus the open outcry system in SIMEX.

    The major provisions of the Bill are as follows.

    (1) Approval and regulation of commodity futures exchanges and clearing house.

    TDB will be empowered to approve the establishment of an exchange and clearing house, amend their business rules and review disciplinary action taken by the exchange against its members.

    (2) Licensing of commodity futures brokers, trading advisers, pool operators and representatives.

    The licensing provisions will regulate the entry and participation of commodity futures brokers, trading advisers, pool operators and representatives. This will safeguard the substantial amounts of customers' funds deposited in good faith with the brokers or the other agents. Specific provisions ensure that the licensing provisions in this Bill and the FTA do not overlap.

    (3) Conduct of commodity futures business.

    The Bill requires funds placed by customers with their brokers to be separately accounted for, to prevent brokers from making use of their client's funds for any other purposes.

    (4) Powers of the TDB to regulate the market.

    The Bill enables the TDB to take emergency action such as terminating or suspending trading, requiring additional margins for any contracts, etc, if it believes this is necessary to protect the customers and the market.

    (5) Provisions for offences to deal with fraudulent practices.

    The Bill spells out the fraudulent trading practices which will constitute offences, such as false trading, bucketing, manipulating of prices and inducing customers to trade by making false statements.

Column: 1348



    In conclusion, the Commodity Futures Bill provides the same system of regulations, offences and penalties as the FTA to ensure that the high standards set by the MAS in financial futures markets are also maintained in the commodity futures business.

    Sir, I beg to move.

    Question put, and agreed to.

    Bill accordingly read a Second time and committed to a Committee of the whole House.

    The House immediately resolved itself into a Committee on the Bill. - [BG Lee Hsien Loong].

    Bill considered in Committee; reported without amendment; read a Third time and passed.

HOUSING AND DEVELOPMENT (AMENDMENT) BILL


    Order for Second Reading read.

     The Minister for National Development (Mr S. Dhanabalan): Mr Speaker, Sir, I beg to move, "That the Bill be now read a Second time."

    The main aim of this Bill is to enable the Housing and Development Board (HDB) to implement the Upgrading Programme for public housing estates. The Bill also includes amendments to enable HDB to sell its tenanted shops to sitting tenants, as well as to expedite the execution of lease and mortgage instruments.

    Mr Speaker, Sir, on 11th July 1989, I informed the House that HDB will implement a major programme, spread over 10 to 15 years, to upgrade the quality of older HDB flats and improve the common areas and open spaces within HDB estates. The Upgrading Programme will be carried out precinct by precinct. Each precinct will be a small area, comprising between five and seven blocks, which residents can identify with, and relate to, as their own.

    The first phase of the Upgrading Programme involves six "demonstration" precincts in Marine Parade, Kim Keat, Telok Blangah, Ang Mo Kio, Clementi and Lorong Lew Lian. By the end of next month, residents in all six precincts would have confirmed whether or not they want their precinct to be upgraded. HDB expects to commence upgrading works in the demonstration precincts starting from the end of

Column: 1349

this year. The Upgrading Programme will be extended to other precincts in phases over the next 10-15 years. The Housing and Development (Amendment) Bill sets out the legislative framework necessary for the smooth implementation of the Upgrading Programme.

    Clause 3 of the Bill introduces a new Part IVA, with new sections 65A to 65L, in the Housing and Development Act dealing with the implementation of the upgrading works in HDB housing estates. In particular, the new section 65A defines the key terms relevant to the Upgrading Programme such as "precinct" and the various types of "upgrading works". A distinction is made between "specified upgrading works" which affect only specific blocks in a precinct, and "general upgrading works" which cover improvements to all the blocks and the common property in a precinct.

    The new section 65B empowers the Minister, after consulting HDB, to declare any HDB housing estate, or any part of it, to be a precinct for the purpose of carrying out upgrading works.

    We will not impose the Upgrading Programme on flat owners. We will be guided by their views. Flat owners in the precinct will decide whether or not to proceed with the upgrading works. The new section 65C requires HDB to conduct a poll of eligible flat owners within the precinct to find out whether or not they want the proposed upgrading. HDB may, with the approval of the Minister, proceed to carry out the proposed package of "general" upgrading works for the precinct if the poll shows that 75% or more of eligible flat owners in the precinct agree to the carrying out of such works. HDB may also carry out "specified" upgrading works affecting a specific block if 75% or more of eligible flat owners in that block are in favour.

    As Members are aware, HDB has conducted polls in Marine Parade and Kim Keat, and an overwhelming majority of flat owners there have supported upgrading. The new section 65C also regularises such polls conducted prior to the coming into force of the amendments proposed in this Bill.

Column: 1350



    The new section 65D authorises HDB to carry out upgrading works in a precinct6, after approval has been given by the Minister, in such a manner as HDB thinks fit. We want to make sure that only improvement works that are valued by flat owners and Town Councils will be carried out under the Upgrading Programme. Affected flat owners and their respective Town Councils will therefore be required to share in the upgrading cost. The new section 65D allows HDB to recover from flat owners and Town Councils their share of the cost of upgrading works. I want to assure Members that flat owners and Town Councils will be well informed of their financial obligations, viz, the percentage and dollar share of upgrading costs before polling begins. The amount to be paid, termed as the "improvement contribution", by each flat owner and Town Council will be determined by HDB.

    From time to time, it might be necessary for HDB to carry out certain improvements in a precinct which are in the public interest, such as the installation of dry risers for fire fighting, upgrading of electrical load and replacement of lift car cage. Such improvement works should be carried out, wherever possible, together with upgrading works that require the majority support of flat owners. This will minimise disruptions to residents. The new section 65E empowers the Minister to direct HDB to carry out such improvement works in a precinct, without conducting a poll. HDB will bear the full cost of such works.

    To help flat owners pay their share of upgrading cost, HDB will provide loans repayable in instalments, by cash or from CPF savings, over a 5- or 10-year period. Arrangements have also been made to help lessees in genuine financial hardship, eg, those who are unemployed. Based on the merits of each case, HDB will consider allowing such lessees to defer their instalment payments with interest for a certain period of time. Lessees who are 55 years of age or older and have no employment, investment income or CPF savings, may be allowed to defer the instalment payments with interest until they sell or transfer their flat.

Column: 1351



    There may, however, be some lessees who, despite being able to pay, deliberately delay or simply refuse to pay up. The new section 65F empowers HDB to impose interest and a penalty for late payment on such lessees. HDB is also empowered under the new section 65H to sell off a flat to recover the improvement contributions if they remain unpaid by such lessees. New section 65I enables HDB to recover any unpaid improvement contributions in any court of competent authority or in any Small Claims Tribunal.

    "Space-adding" items, such as an utility room, bathroom or service balcony, will result in an increase in the floor area of the flats. The flat owner must be given proper title to the additional space created. Normal conveyancing practice requires flat owners to sign a number of legal documents and pay the necessary stamp and legal fees to vest the title. The new section 65G simplifies this procedure to involve only HDB and the Registry of Titles. HDB will lodge the necessary legal documents with the Registrar of Titles. The flat owners will not be required to sign any legal documents, or pay any stamp or legal fees.

    The new section 65J empowers any officer or person authorised by HDB to enter any flat or building within a precinct to carry out upgrading works within the flat or building. Those who wilfully obstruct the authorised officer or person will be guilty of an offence, and will be liable to a fine on conviction.

    The powers of entry into a flat provided by new section 65J are necessary for the smooth implementation of upgrading works. They will also minimise disruptions to the daily life of residents in a precinct. HDB will have to work out very carefully and adhere strictly to the implementation schedule for upgrading works. Each flat owner will be informed in advance of the exact date and duration that works will be carried out within his flat. A flat owner can then arrange for someone to be present in the flat when work is being carried out within the flat.
